item.title: Designing Useful Smart Home Notifications
item.content:encoded: Smart-home notifications should be timely, relevant, specific, and personalized to avoid overwhelming users and causing distrust or disengagement.

item.title: Tracking Adoption of Research Recommendations: The Recommendation-Adoption Score
item.content:encoded: Use the RAS (Recommendation-Adoption Score) to track how much research value reaches your user.

item.title: UX Conference May Announced (May 11 - May 22)
item.content:encoded: Take up to 5 in-depth training courses, teaching user experience best practices for successful design. Training focused on long-lasting skills for UX professionals. May 11 - May 22, 2026.

item.title: UX Research with Minors: Consent vs. Assent
item.content:encoded: When conducting UX research with minors, you must obtain consent from a parent or legal guardian and assent from the minor participant.

item.title: What UX Consulting Clients Expect in the Age of AI
item.content:encoded: Clients still seek strong judgment and critical thinking, research rigor, and respect for real-world and user constraints from UX consultants.

item.title: How AI Literacy Shapes GenAI Use
item.content:encoded: Using generative AI often doesn’t mean using it well. AI literacy requires both prompt fluency and the ability to assess outputs.

item.title: Your Design System Needs an Enforcer
item.content:encoded: Although design systems promise consistency, most still fail without someone actively enforcing the rules and making teams follow them.

item.title: AI-Moderated Interviews: If, When, and How to Use Them
item.content:encoded: AI interviews offer faster feedback at scale, but they're not a replacement for in-depth, human-led semistructured interviews.

item.title: Demand Accuracy in Your AI Tools: Lessons from Baymard Institute
item.content:encoded: Most AI-powered tools for UX lack reliability and accountability in their outputs. Demand transparency and proven accuracy, or don't buy it.

item.title: User Panels 101
item.content:encoded: A well-built internal user panel saves time, reduces costs, and strengthens your organization’s connection to real users.

item.title: Why So Many Info Tips Are Bad (and How to Make Them Better)
item.content:encoded: Information tips can clarify complex UIs, but they should not hide essential information, trigger redundant information, or disrupt the current workflow.

item.title: Job Opening: UX Design Assistant (Remote, World-Wide; Europe Based)
item.content:encoded: We’re looking for a talented UX design assistant to join the team. Applications due February 6, 2026.

item.title: Job Opening: UX Design Assistant (Remote, World-Wide; US Based)
item.content:encoded: We’re looking for a talented UX design assistant to join the team. Applications due February 6, 2026.

item.content:encoded: We’re looking for a talented social media design assistant to join the team. Applications due February 6, 2026.

item.content:encoded: We’re looking for a talented social media design assistant to join the team. Applications due February 6, 2026.

item.title: UX Conference April Announced (Apr 13 - Apr 17)
item.content:encoded: Take up to 5 in-depth training courses, teaching user experience best practices for successful design. Courses focused on long-lasting skills for UX professionals. April 13 - April 17, 2026.

item.title: UX Hiring: Insights from a Design Recruiter
item.content:encoded: Design recruiter Hang Xu shares why UX job applications get rejected, what craft means to hiring teams, and the shifting power dynamics in the job market.

item.title: State of UX 2026: Design Deeper to Differentiate
item.content:encoded: UX faced instability in 2025 from layoffs, hiring freezes, and AI hype; now, the field is stabilizing, but differentiation and business impact are vital.

item.title: Why Most Product Teams Aren't Really Empowered
item.content:encoded: Although product teams say they're empowered, many still function as feature factories and must follow orders.

item.title: Humanizing AI Is a Trap
item.content:encoded: LLMs humanize by design. Adding personality/emotion amplifies risk. Design real tools, not fake friends.
